providerHelp.Name: Mongo
providerHelp.Synopsis: Provides access to MongoDB servers, collections, documents, indexes, and users.

DetailedDescription.para:
The Mongo provider for Windows PowerShell lets you work with MongoDB databases from your PowerShell session.
The provider exposes a Windows PowerShell drive with a directory structure that corresponds to your MongoDB server databases, collections, and documents.
Directory Hierarchy ------------------- The directory hierarchy of the Mongo provider is outlined below. Items listed [in brackets] represent variable content that will change based on your database content.
MongoDB:\ --- [Database]\ ------------- [Collection]\ ------------------------- [Document]\ ------------------------- [Index]\ ------------- [User]\
Custom Provider Help -------------------- Custom help is available for most item cmdlets in the Mongo Provider heirarchy. To get help for an item cmdlet as it applies to a specific location, pass the location to the -path parameter of get-help. For example:
get-help new-item -path mongo:/MyDB/MyColl
You can also change the current location to the area of interest on the dte: drive and invoke get-help for the cmdlet in question:
c:\gt;set-location mongo:\MyDB\MyColl mongo:\MyDB\MyColl>get-help new-item

Introduction.para: This command mounts a mongodb server as a new PowerShell drive.

Remarks.para: the new-psdrive cmdlet is extended with several parameters to define the connection to the mongodb server(s). this example demonstrates the use of the connectionstring parameter.

Introduction.para: This command mounts a mongodb replica set as a new PowerShell drive.

Remarks.para: the new-psdrive cmdlet is extended with several parameters to define the connection to the mongodb server(s). this example demonstrates the use of the servers parameter.

Introduction.para: This command mounts a mongodb server as a new PowerShell drive, and defines connection pooling options.

Remarks.para: the new-psdrive cmdlet is extended with several parameters to define the connection to the mongodb server(s). this example demonstrates the use of the servers, pooled, connectionTimeout, minimumPoolSize, and maximumPoolSize parameters.

Introduction.para: This command mounts a mongodb server as a new PowerShell drive and verifies the connection immediately.

Remarks.para: the new-psdrive cmdlet is extended with several parameters to define the connection to the mongodb server(s). this example demonstrates the use of the connectionstring and verify parameters.

Introduction.para: This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list the databases in the MongoDB server(s).
This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list the collections and database users in the MyDB database.
This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list all documents and collection indexes in the MyColl collection.
This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list documents in the MyColl collection. A native filter is applied using the custom -Find parameter so only documents where Name is Jim are returned.

Remarks.para: The hashtable passed to the -Find parameter should be simple string=>value pairs. For nested document properties, use the dot-syntax supported by native filters (see EXAMPLE 4.1)

Introduction.para: This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list documents in the MyColl collection. A native filter is applied using the custom -Find parameter so only documents containing a Customer document with a Name equal to Jim are returned.

This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list documents in the MyColl collection. A native filter is applied using the custom -Find parameter so only documents containing a SKU property matching the specified regular expression are returned.
This command uses the Set-Location command to change the current location to a database named MyDB. Use a backslash (\) or forward slash (/) to indicate a level of the drive.

Remarks.para: While PowerShell is not case sensitive, MongoDB is case sensitive. All paths in the MongoDB provider should be specified in explicit case.

Introduction.para: This command uses the Set-Location command to change the current location to a collection named MyColl in the MyDB database. Use a backslash (\) or forward slash (/) to indicate a level of the drive.

Remarks.para: While PowerShell is not case sensitive, MongoDB is case sensitive. All paths in the MongoDB provider should be specified in explicit case.

Task.Title: Listing Items on the MongoDB Drive

Introduction.para: This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list the databases in the MongoDB server(s).
This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list the collections and database users in the MyDB database.
This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list all documents and collection indexes in the MyColl collection.
This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list documents in the MyColl collection. A native filter is applied using the custom -Find parameter so only documents where Name is Jim are returned.

Remarks.para: The hashtable passed to the -Find parameter should be simple string=>value pairs. For nested document properties, use the dot-syntax supported by native filters (see EXAMPLE 4.1)

Introduction.para: This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list documents in the MyColl collection. A native filter is applied using the custom -Find parameter so only documents containing a Customer document with a Name equal to Jim are returned.

This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list documents in the MyColl collection. A native filter is applied using the custom -Find parameter so only documents containing a SKU property matching the specified regular expression are returned.
This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list documents in the MyColl collection. A cursor limit is applied using the custom -Limit parameter so only 5 documents are returned.

This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list documents in the MyColl collection. A cursor filter, limit, and skip is applied using the custom -Find, -Limit, and -Skip parameters, resulting in the 100th - 105th documents containing a SKU property matching the specified regular expression being returned.
This command uses the Get-ChildItems command to list documents in the MyColl collection. A cursor filter and field specification is applied using the custom -Find and -Fields parameters.

Task.Title: Creating New Databases, Collections, Users, and Indexes

Introduction.para: This command uses the New-Item command to create a new database named MyOtherDB.
This command uses the New-Item command to create a new collection named Coll2 in database MyOtherDB.

Remarks.para: When creating a collection, the -type parameter is optional.

Introduction.para: This command uses the New-Item command to create a new user for database MyOtherDB.

Remarks.para: When creating a database user, the -type parameter and value of 'user' are required.
You may omit the password value, in which case your PowerShell host will prompt you for one securely.

Introduction.para: This command uses the New-Item command to create a new collection index on collection Coll2 in database MyOtherDB. The index is ascending on the Name field.
This command creates a new document in the Coll2 collection of the MyOtherDB database.

Example.Title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 6.1 --------------------------

Introduction.para: This command pipes objects to the New-Item command to store file information in the MyOtherDB.Coll2 collection.

Example.Code: Get-ChildItem c:\ | Select-Object -property Name,DirectoryName,CreationTime | New-Item -path m:/MyOtherDB/Coll2

Remarks.para: The MongoDB provider will attempt to translate every property of the input object into a document field. This can be expensive if you provide a deep object tree. In this example, the Select-Object cmdlet is used to cull the object fields down to Name, DirectoryName, and CreationTime.

Introduction.para: This command uses the Get-Item and Set-Item commands to retrieve and update an existing document.
This command uses the Get-Item command to create a new collection index on collection Coll2 in database MyOtherDB. The index is ascending on the Name field.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new project or solution folder, or adds an existing project to the solution.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to create a new project or solution folder, or to add an existing project to the solution.
Specifies the code language to use for the project.
The name of the new project.
The name of a project template to create, or "folder" to create a folder.
The path to the solution projects node.
The name of the new code element.
Identifies a path to an existing item that should be added to the solution.
Specifies the code language to use for the project.
Identifies a path to an existing item that should be added to the solution.
Identifies the name of a project template to create, or "folder" to create a solution folder. For a list of all project templates, see the dte:/templates/projects node.
You cannot pipe a value to the New-Item cmdlet at this location.
The New-Item cmdlet adds the project or folder to the solution and returns the object for the project or folder.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new class library project named MyClassLibrary. The new project will be coded in C#.
This command adds an existing project to the current solution.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new project item to the project.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to add an item to a project.
The path to the project node.
The name of the item to add.
The type of project item to add. Can be "folder" to create a project folder, or it can be the name of a valid project item template.
The language to use for the new project item.
The path to the project node.
The name of the item to add.
The path of an existing item to add to the project.
The language to use for the new project item.
The type of project item to add. Can be "folder" or the name of a valid item template. For a list of availabe project item templates, see dte:\templates\projectItems.
The name of the new item. Note that this should contain the appropriate file extension for the language used.
The path to the project node.
The file path to the item being added to the project.
The values piped to New-Item at this location are ignored.
The New-Item cmdlet creates the specified project item and returns the project item object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new breakpoint at line 17 in file Program.cs.
This command adds a breakpoint to the Execute method of the MyClass class.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds an assembly reference to a project.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to add an assembly reference to a project.
The path to the project references container.
The GUID of the com object type library.
The type of reference to add. Can be "com"
The major version number of the type library to reference.
The minor version number of the type library to reference.
The locale identifier of the type library to reference.
The .NET code wrapper tool to use.
The path to the project references container.
The project or assembly name to reference.
The type of reference to add. Can be "project" or "assembly"
The type of reference to add. Can be "project", "assembly", or "com"
The locale identifier of COM the type library to reference.
The major version of COM the type library to reference.
The minor version of COM the type library to reference.
The name of the .NET project or assembly to reference, or the GUID of the com object type library.
The path to the breakpoint container.
The .NET code wrapper tool to use.
The values piped to New-Item at this location are ignored.
The New-Item cmdlet creates the specified breakpoint and returns the breakpoint object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new breakpoint at line 17 in file Program.cs.
This command adds a breakpoint to the Execute method of the MyClass class.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds an error to the error task list.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to add an error task to the errors window.
The path to the errors container.
The category of error to add. Can be "error", "message", or "warning"
The description of the new error task.
The line number associated with the error.
The column number associated with the error.
The file path of the code or project file associated with the error.
The category of error to add. Can be "error", "message", or "warning"
The description of the error.
The line number associated with the error.
The column number associated with the error.
The path to the breakpoint container.
The file path of the code or project file associated with the error.
Each value pipes to the New-Item cmdlet at this location will become a new error task.
The New-Item cmdlet creates the specified error task and returns the error task object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-Item -path . -value "The cake is a lie" -type warning

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the warning "The cake is a lie" to the errors window.
This command adds an error message to the error window indicating that the file myscript.ps1 is broken.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a task to the task list.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to add a task to the task list.
The path to the tasks container.
The task category.
The description of the new task.
The line number associated with the task.
The task priority.
The task icon.
Indicates that the task contains a checkbox.
Indicates that the task cannot be deleted by the user.
When specified, prevents the task from being flushed to the task window.
The file associated with this task.
The path to the tasks container.
The task category.
The description of the new task.
The line number associated with the task.
The task priority.
The task icon.
Indicates that the task contains a checkbox.
Indicates that the task cannot be deleted by the user.

When specified, prevents the task from being flushed to the task window. This can be useful when creating large numbers of tasks to prevent slow performance as each task is displayed in the tasks window.
The file associated with this task.
Each value pipes to the New-Item cmdlet at this location will become a new error task.
The New-Item cmdlet creates the specified error task and returns the error task object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a task to the task window reminding the user to take a break in 15 minutes.
This command adds a task "call Jennifer" to the task window with a high priority

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new command bar.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to create a new command bar. Command bars make up the menus and toolbars of the Visual Studio IDE.
The name of the new command bar.
The current position of the command bar.
When specified, indicates the command bar is temporary and should not persist past the current IDE session.
The current position of the command bar.
When specified, indicates the command bar is temporary and should not persist past the current IDE session.
You cannot pipe a value to the New-Item cmdlet at this location.
The New-Item cmdlet adds the command bar the heirarchy and returns the object for the new command bar.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new command bar named "PSake Commands Menu".

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new control in a command bar or popup menu.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to create a new control, such as a button, popup menu, or drop down.
The path to the command bar.
The name of the new command bar control.
The type of control to create.
The caption of the new control, including any & key accelerators.
The 1-based position of the new command bar control.
The control ID.
The caption or label for the control, including any & key accelerators. If unspecified the Name parameter value is used.
The type of control to create. Appropriate values for this path include "button", "combobox", and "popup".
The control ID.
The path to the command bar or popup control.
The 1-based position of the new control.
You cannot pipe a value to the New-Item cmdlet at this location.
The New-Item cmdlet adds the command bar the heirarchy and returns the object for the new command bar.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a new menu item on the main help menu named "Click Me". The script associated with the control outputs the date to the output pane.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------

maml:introduction.maml:para: DTE:\commandBars:\context menus\Project and Solution Context Menus\Project>

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a new menu item on the project context menu. The script associated with the control changes the current location of the StudioShell console to the location of the selected project node.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new Visual Studio command.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to create a new command. Commands are executed in response to IDE events, such as clicking on a toolbar button or pressing a key combination.
The path to the commands node.
The name of the new command.
The name of the command, as shown in the UI.
The tooltip for the command.
The key bindings for the command.
The PowerShell script block to associate with the command.
The key bindings for the command. Specify a list of string that include CTRL, ALT, SHIFT, and standard key names.
The name of the command, as shown in the UI.
The name of the new command.
The path to the commands node.
The tooltip for the command.
The PowerShell script block to associate with the command.
You can pipe a script block value to the New-Item cmdlet at this location.
The New-Item cmdlet adds the command to the IDE and returns the object for the new command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example defines a new IDE command that copies new GUID values to the clipboard. The command is bound to the key combination Control + Alt + G.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates an existing Visual Studio command.
At this path location, you can use the Set-Item cmdlet to update the key bindings or associated script block of a command.
The path to the commands node.
The key bindings for the command.
The PowerShell script block to associate with the command.
The key bindings for the command. Specify a list of string that include CTRL, ALT, SHIFT, and standard key names.
The path to the commands node.
The PowerShell script block to associate with the command.
You can pipe a script block value to the New-Item cmdlet at this location.
The Set-Item cmdlet updates the key bindings and script block for the command and returns the object for the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example updates the existing NewGuidToClipboard command with a new key binding.

This command adds a breakpoint to the Execute method of the MyClass class.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new file-level code element.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to create a new file-level code element, such as a namespace, or import statement.
The path to the code element container.
The name of the new code element.
The position of the new code element. Use 0 to place at the beginning, -1 to place at the end, or specify an explicit index value.
The list of base types for the new class or struct.
The list of implemented interfaces for the new class, struct, or interface.
The access level, either public, private, protected, internal, or protected internal.
The type of code element to create.
The path to the code element container.
The name of the new code element.
The position of the new code element. Use 0 to place at the beginning, -1 to place at the end, or specify an explicit index value.

The base type for the new class or struct.
The list of implemented interfaces for the new class, struct, or interface.
The type of code element to create. Appropriate values for this path include "import", "class", and "namespace".
The name of the new code element.
The path to the code element container.
The position of the new code element. Use 0 to place at the beginning, -1 to place at the end, or specify an explicit index value.
You can pipe a variable or attribute parameter value to the New-Item cmdlet at this location.
The New-Item cmdlet adds the specified code element to the code model and returns the added code element.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new namespace named MyOtherNamespace in the Program.cs file code model.
This command adds a new import (using) statement for the System.IO namespace to the Program.cs file code model.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new public class named MyClass in the namespace MyNamespace.
This command adds a new internal delegate type named MyDelegate to the MyNamespace namespace.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new enumeration member or enumeration attribute.
At this path location, you can use the New-Item cmdlet to create a new enumeration member or enumeration attribute.
The path to the code element container.
The name of the new code element.
The position of the new code element. Use 0 to place at the beginning, -1 to place at the end, or specify an explicit index value.
The type of code element to create.
A comma separated list of parameter values.
The type of code element to create. Appropriate values for this path include "variable" to create a new enumeration member, or "attribute" to create a new enumeration attribute.
The path to the code element container.
The position of the new code element. Use 0 to place at the beginning, -1 to place at the end, or specify an explicit index value.
The value of the enumeration member or attribute parameters.

The New-Item cmdlet adds the specified code element to the code model and returns the added code element.

This command decorates the MyEnum enumeration with a Serializable attribute.
